intro: Acanthus hirsutus, commonly known as the hairy acanthus, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its large, palmate leaves that are covered in soft, hairy textures. The plant produces showy, spiny flower spikes that bloom in late summer. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for ornamental gardening. Its unique foliage and architectural form make it a striking addition to gardens and landscapes.

Its genus is Acanthus, a group of flowering plants commonly known for their spiny leaves and showy flowers, often used in horticulture. Its species is Acanthus hirsutus, a specific variety within the Acanthus genus characterized by its hairy leaves and distinctive floral structure.

Acanthus hirsutus is often seen growing in limestone formations and along cliffs. Its distribution reflects its adaptation to the specific environmental conditions of the eastern Mediterranean.

It is commonly used in gardens and as a decorative plant in urban environments. The plant has been introduced to various regions outside its native range, including parts of Europe and North America.
